key_points: Four months into her vice presidency, Kamala Harris experiences challenges in defining her role.
Harris's role is crucial for the Democratic Party, seen as a potential future presidential candidate.
She navigates managing a new staff, building a relationship with President Biden, and adapting to an evolving portfolio.
Harris participates actively in public events and foreign relations, also focusing on vaccine outreach and equity in COVID-19 response.
Some Democrats express concerns about Harris not carving out a distinct path separate from President Biden.
Harris's historical firsts as vice president include being the first woman, Black person, and Indian American.
Her political charisma contrasts with Biden's more reserved persona, raising questions about her overshadowing him.
Critics and strategists debate the clarity and definition of Harris's responsibilities, particularly concerning immigration and foreign policy.
Lawmakers praise Harris's openness and engagement, indicative of her potential influence on policy and the party's future.
There's anticipation that Harris's role will become more defined over time, emphasizing her importance in upcoming elections and the Democratic Party.
spokespersons: Anita McBride (assistant to President George W. Bush and chief of staff to first lady Laura Bush)
Rep. Judy Chu (D-Calif., chairwoman of the Congressional Asian Pacific American Caucus)
